abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, but the institutional development
            impact was only modest. Among the lessons drawn from the
            project, particular attention needs to be given to the
            policies related to input distribution, credit, and produce
            marketing, to ensure adequate incentives among farmers,
            needed for a successful technology transfer. In addition,
            complementary investments to technology development should
            be ensured in the project design, as well as a decentralized
            rural development management, and a robust infrastructure.
            The government needs to ensure the adequate rapport between
            the public sector, and donor agencies, to attain
            complementary arrangements, rather than duplication among
            agencies. This rapport would also facilitate a focused
            allocation of limited public funds, to priority
            interventions for rural development. The flaws in uneconomic
            procurement, lack of transparency in the process, and
            exceeding aggregate limits prescribed for the procurement of
            goods, and services, reveal the need of a strong
            supervision, which should include skilled staff in financial
            management, and procurement.
